articles.headline: Daschle Knew of Tax Issues Over Car Use Last June
articles.snippet: Tom Daschle did not warn the Obama team of his back taxes issue until weeks after his cabinet nomination.
articles.abstract: Tom Daschle did not warn the Obama team of his back taxes issue until weeks after his cabinet nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s choice for health secretary, Tom Daschle, was aware as early as last June that he might have to pay back taxes for the use of a car and driver provided by a private equity firm, but did not inform the Obama transition team until weeks after Mr. Obama named him to the health secretary’s post, senior administration officials said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Secular Parties and Premier Lead in Iraq
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and secular parties scored gains in provincial elections, early reports showed.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and secular parties scored gains in provincial elections, early reports showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and several secular parties appeared to score significant gains in Iraq’s provincial elections on Saturday, preliminary reports showed Sunday.

articles.headline: When Even Condé Nast Is in Retreat
articles.snippet: The recent closing of Domino magazine shows that even Condé Nast’s legendary patience to turn a profit is now meeting the pull of economic gravity.
articles.abstract: The recent closing of Domino magazine shows that even Condé Nast’s legendary patience to turn a profit is now meeting the pull of economic gravity.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The September Issue,” a documentary about how the staff of Vogue puts together that curio of profligacy, the magazine’s fall preview, was a big hit at the recent Sundance Film Festival. Part of the reason attendees found it so mesmerizing has to do with Anna Wintour, who always begets staring.

articles.headline: Ads That Pushed Our Usual (Well-Worn) Buttons
articles.snippet: Few of the commercials during Super Bowl XLIII offered anything special.
articles.abstract: Few of the commercials during Super Bowl XLIII offered anything special.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent months, Americans have been disappointed and appalled by Wall Street, banks, the big-budget film “Australia,” investment counselors, Detroit, the governors of at least two states, hedge fund managers and even the geese at La Guardia, which used to know better than to interfere with those metal birds they fly among.

articles.headline: A Tech Mogul’s Green Thumb
articles.snippet: Michael S. Dell got rich building computers, but the tech mogul has interests in many surprisingly low-tech sectors, including the landscaping business.
articles.abstract: Michael S. Dell got rich building computers, but the tech mogul has interests in many surprisingly low-tech sectors, including the landscaping business.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALABASAS, Calif.  Michael S. Dell got rich building computers. His innovation was in pruning the PC supply chain and trimming production costs to undercut his competitors on price.

articles.headline: Despite iTunes Accord, Music Labels Still Fret
articles.snippet: The tension between Apple and the music industry stems from Apple’s power over the industry, but it also echoes the traditional divide between suppliers and distributors.
articles.abstract: The tension between Apple and the music industry stems from Apple’s power over the industry, but it also echoes the traditional divide between suppliers and distributors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month the music industry and Apple, long uneasy partners, seemed a picture of harmony when they agreed on new terms for pricing on iTunes, Apple’s online music store.

articles.headline: February Blues After the Worst of Januarys
articles.snippet: As investors tallied their losses at the end of 2008, they comforted themselves with the thought that at least things could not get much worse. But yes, they can.
articles.abstract: As investors tallied their losses at the end of 2008, they comforted themselves with the thought that at least things could not get much worse. But yes, they can.
articles.lead_paragraph: As investors tallied their losses at the end of 2008, they comforted themselves with the thought that at least things could not get much worse.

articles.headline: Big Risks for U.S. in Trying to Value Bad Bank Assets
articles.snippet: Hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars are at stake as the Obama administration prepares its strategy to rescue the nation’s banks.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of billions of taxpayer dollars are at stake as the Obama administration prepares its strategy to rescue the nation’s banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration prepares its strategy to rescue the nation’s banks by buying or guaranteeing troubled assets on their books, it confronts one central problem: How should they be valued?
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Tougher Border Can’t Stop Mexican Marijuana Cartels
articles.snippet: Despite enforcement on both sides of the Southwest border, the Mexican marijuana trade is more robust than ever, law enforcement officials say.
articles.abstract: Despite enforcement on both sides of the Southwest border, the Mexican marijuana trade is more robust than ever, law enforcement officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Drug smugglers parked a car transport trailer against the Mexican side of the border one day in December, dropped a ramp over the security fence, and drove two pickup trucks filled with marijuana onto Arizona soil.

articles.headline: Welfare Aid Isn’t Growing as Economy Drops Off
articles.snippet: Despite soaring unemployment, the number of people receiving cash assistance remained at or near the lowest in more than 40 years.
articles.abstract: Despite soaring unemployment, the number of people receiving cash assistance remained at or near the lowest in more than 40 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite soaring unemployment and the worst economic crisis in decades, 18 states cut their welfare rolls last year, and nationally the number of people receiving cash assistance remained at or near the lowest in more than 40 years.

articles.headline: A State With a Wish List for Stimulus Spending
articles.snippet: No matter the stimulus package’s final form, experts say that California will most likely be a reliable indicator of the plan’s success or failure.
articles.abstract: No matter the stimulus package’s final form, experts say that California will most likely be a reliable indicator of the plan’s success or failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In charge of 1,200 miles of weather-beaten roads in rural California, Pat Minturn knows exactly where he would spend the $4 million his office hopes to receive from the federal stimulus package.

articles.headline: In Daschle’s Tax Woes, a Peek Into Washington
articles.snippet: The disclosures about Tom Daschle show how he was able to live lavishly by dint of his name and connections.
articles.abstract: The disclosures about Tom Daschle show how he was able to live lavishly by dint of his name and connections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Tom Daschle, the former Democratic Senate leader, had been voted out of office. His close friend Leo Hindery, a Democratic donor and media mogul, was out of a job too, having just sold his stake in Yes Network.
